In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.

 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk.

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk.

When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk.

When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk.

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk.

When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk.

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your wor

 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a townb

When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your one day off to help pick up ga

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your one day off to help a new school fun

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk.

Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk.

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your one day off to help with a school fundraiser. It can be as simple as following your towns

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your one day off to help with a school fundraiser. It can be as simple as following your town or school districts social media page. C

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower.  Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your one day off to help with a school fundraiser. It can be as simple as following your town or school districts social media page. Check for a historical page on your preferred socia

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your one day off to help with a school fundraiser. It can be as simple as following your town or school districts social media page. Check for a historical page on your preferred social media and see what your house looke

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your one day off to help with a school fundraiser. It can be as simple as following your town or school districts social media page. Check for a historical page on your preferred social media and see what your property

 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your one day off to help with a school fundraiser. It can be as simple as following your town or school districts social media page. Check for a historical page on your preferred social media and see what your property looked like 80 years ago

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your one day off to help with a school fundraiser. It can be as simple as following your town or school districts social media page. Check for a historical page on your preferred social media and see what your property looked like 80 years ago, connect with others do

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your one day off to help with a school fundraiser. It can be as simple as following your town or school districts social media page. Check for a historical page on your preferred social media and see what your property looked like 80 years ago, connect with others doing the same. Next thing you know, you have a cu

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your one day off to help with a school fundraiser. It can be as simple as following your town or school districts social media page. Check for a historical page on your preferred social media and see what your property looked like 80 years ago, connect with others doing the same. Next thing you know, you have a connection with you

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your one day off to help with a school fundraiser. It can be as simple as following your town or school districts social media page. Check for a historical page on your preferred social media and see what your property looked like 80 years ago, connect with others doing the same. Next thing you know, you have a connection with your fellow citizens with

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk.

Next thing you know, you have a connection with your fellow citizens without having to deal with

Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your one day off to help with a school fundraiser. It can be as simple as following your town or school districts social media page. Check for a historical page on your preferred social media and see what your property looked like 80 years ago, connect with others doing the same. Next thing you know, you have a connection with your fellow citizens without having to deal with the negatives of the

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, they are not being bad citizens if they don't keep up with the news, but they ARE harming themselves and potentially others by not understanding what is going on in the city, state, country or world.  
When people don't keep up with the news it becomes easier to separate themselves from everything and everyone else.
 Initially, you aren't aware the problem exists, then when you finally become aware that it IS a problem, you don't think it will affect you and you ignore it. You dismiss it and it becomes easy to focus on the only things that "matter" to you, which becomes narrower and narrower. Next thing you know, you have a town vote on a safety matter and you and others like you have no say in the problem and the unsafe decision is made before you understand the repercussions.  

Saturating yourself with the current evens can be equally as bad, you become jaded and start the view the issue as "blown out of proportion". o understand the bigger picture and to not become ignorant to the problems, but rather informed of them, is important , albeit a fine line to walk. 

Engaging in current events inside of your local city or town doesn't have to mean changing your work hours to go to a township meeting or using your one day off to help with a school fundraiser. It can be as simple as following your town or school districts social media page. Check for a historical page on your preferred social media and see what your property looked like 80 years ago, connect with others doing the same. Next thing you know, you have a connection with your fellow citizens without having to deal with the negatives of one major situation
